text: Â @Edmonton RailsÂ  It is the most basic form of science, there is a natural climate change which is strongly amplified by the human emission of greenhouse Gases. The natural climate change, caused by the sun can be measured in any proper observatory, there are tens of thousands of them on earth, do you think they are all lying? All of them are observing that the rapid increase in global temperature isn't due to the sun or any other cosmic reason. The only thing is technically able to warm up planet earth as fast as we seed it right now, is a rapid change in atmospheric composition, aka an increase in greenhouse Gases. Who makes greenhouse Gases? Kinda obvious eh?
author: Aumann04

text: Â @Aumann04Â   No, there are not thousands of observatories that properly monitor the sun and all cosmic factors. There are a small handful of satellites in space that monitor solar particles, and their data is yet to enter mainstream climate science. There are 30+ factors of solar and cosmic influence on earth's climate, and only 1 (direct visible sunlight) is included in mainstream climate models. The strongest greenhouse gas on earth by far is water vapor. Meanwhile, water vapor condensed into clouds is a cooling factor. Water vapor requires a particle to condense into clouds, and this particle is often a cosmic ray. The amount of cosmic rays entering the atmosphere is influenced by the strength of solar wind, which greatly fluctuates. The sun also electro-magnetically heats the earth through atmospheric electric circuits, the same system that helps energize thunder storms. The sun outputs many high energy particles other than direct sunlight. In some cases, so many high energy particles are emitted that they dim visible sunlight by 1%. Despite these high energy particles having a strong heating effect on the earth the climate models count these events as a reduction in solar power, as direct sunlight has dimmed. Those are just 3 major factors that are conveniently ignored by mainstream climate science. This isn't about a grand conspiracy, it's about career scientists towing the line and protecting their cushy jobs and funding. It's an office job, writing reports off the same regurgitated data over and over because it pays.

text: If you couldn't detect that the "scientist" Hansen was a consummate liar, then you are brain dead. Johnson doesn't claim to be a scientist, but like 99% of people on both sides of the climate "debate" (including the plethora of scientists who know nothing about climate) depend on expert opinion and have to judge who to believe. I, for one, and probably Sen. Johnson too, trust the judgement of Richard Lindzen and thousands of true climate scientists who agree with his analysis. Johnson's point was well taken. For thousands of years there have been trends of climate change in both directions. The amount of measurable climate change in recent years is way too small to definitively say the trend is heading toward disaster. That is Lindzen's opinion. Other experts on atmospheric CO2 claim the increase from 180ppm to 380ppm in the past 150 years is good for the atmosphere by increasing green plant life and O2. As a matter of fact 180ppm was dangerously low, at below 150ppm, plant life cannot be sustained.

text: I didnt see him schooling anyone, what i seen was someone coming up with excuses, if it is that clear cut and dry then all the rest of the climate scientist would be on board. almost half of climate scientist  /a meteorologist do not agree in manmade climate change. Is the climate always changing yes anyone that denies that is an idiot. Before someone says that is inaccurate u better do some research. I forgot how many thousands of the worlds climate and meteorologist scientist were polled in 2019 if they believed man had an affect on climate change, barely over 50% believed that. Then we get into other scientist around the were geologist and many other fields and that number is even less in favor  of man made climate change, and one of the main points of contention with them is they all say they do not include solar activity in there models  That 97% of the worlds scientist believe in manmade climate change has been proven false many times now yet many keep spouting that nonsense.  I believe there is a lot we still do not know, I also believe we should start striving for cleaner energy, I dont have a problem with that, but the ruining of millions of lives by making the change so drastically without that gradual change is not the way to do it. I believe people need to clean up after themselves and stop polluting the ocean and the land, and stop killing and abusing everything in this world . But the bottom line is if u still have not convinced the rest of the scientist or atleast the majority of them then u shouldnt expect there to be enough to convince normal people. I can even post u several videos one of which, a main stream news channel digs into the story, shows where the 97% myth started, and went around interviewing  climate and meteorologist scientist that did not believe in man made climate change. She was asking them why they didnt believe that and talked about  research done i think at cambridge university and a prestigious american university, where they polled thousands of climate and meteorologist if they believed man was affecting climate change, and just over half believed man was affecting it. Many of them said the same thing i said that solar activity is not taken into account in climate models. That they know for a fact solar activity has been high for last couple decades. So how can concencensus be reached if leaving out important information. There is also the fact that Nasa changed the data and has admitted as much on global temperatures, there reason was that they believed there were inaccuracies so they were trying to account for that. There is another group of scientist of several thousand that formed a group to prove man isnt affecting the climate, and they say the data was accurate, but the data didnt help man made climate change agenda because, the pre changed data shows without a shadow of a doubt that there is no man made climate change. No correlation between co2 and rise in temperature. That group consist of climate scientist, meteorologist, geologist, ecologist, astronomist, oceanography, and atmospheric  scientist. Quite a big group that looks at more than one point of data that looks at it all and comparing it. So its not just as simple as one group denies it with no evidence, the burden of proof falls on the one claiming it, and the vast majority have said that has not been done. You have a lot of scientist in those fields u need to convince before u can convince an entire population of the earth.

text:
Â @Soroush MirghasemiÂ  temperature has been rising for the past 200,000 years, carbon has only a part in temperature rise. As you know, co2 can only absorb a part of the radiation spectrum and the effects of co2 on temperature is logarithmic, we even is the amount of co2 doubles, the temperature would barely change.

Earths atmosphere always tries to reach an equilibrium with energy absorbed and emitted. Things that play a role are: atmosphere gas's composition, gravity, temperature of sun's radiation, density of plant life and earth's rotation and revolution.

I mentioned earlier the heating since 200,000 years, that's because the last time the earth's axis shifted, we got the ice age but that was a big shift. Recently there has been a shift noted bit it's only a few degrees. Similarly, the sun's rays have been hotter than before.

It's all multifactorial and these scientists ignoring these common facts makes skepticis more confident in their theories.

text:

author: Boe Jiden

text:
Â @Boe JidenÂ  the first two paragraphs you mentioned are completely known and acknowledged by the scientific community, of course everyone knows that there are multiple factors in the climate changing (this occurs in natural cycles like the season and more complex centurial cycles) but from the data we have collected we understand that since the industrial revolution global temperatures are on the rise and this rise is directly correlative with the increased emissions of CO2 and other greenhouse gases (of course there is natural variation that has to be factored for the effect to be seen clearly.) scientists also know that only a portion of the electromagnetic spectrum is absorbed by co2 ( else you would be exhaling black smoke because the co2 would be absorbing the visible light) it absorbs like in the inferred frequency which is heat that is radiated from the sun and traps it in the form of kinetic energy in the atmosphere (this is for example why the surface of Venus is so hot compared to mercury which is closer to the sun.) the correlation is logarithmic,  but that works against your argument as even small amount of greenhouse gases lead to huge effects on global temperatures ( again though you have to control for other factors you canâ€™t just put a graph of global temperatures vs greenhouse gases in the atmosphere and expect it to correlate perfectly even though it would look really close). The third paragraph is just a reiteration which I explained.
About the axis shift I would ask you to provide me a study that claims that the effects of current climate change can be explained by a shift in the axis of the earth( again current) and Iâ€™d be willing to discuss it.
So in short you just ignore what the scientific community is saying and say that they are the ones ignoring the factors they themselves discovered.

text: The senator's grasp of the issue is far from perfect.  But the "scientist" simply evades the critical question.  While the currently observed change over the 100-150 years is (likely) due to human activity, what are we to do about much larger swings that are entirely outside of human capacity to control?  Is "stop all technology" or "solely renewable energy" a sensible recipe for human long-term survival?   If you want something "natural" you make yourself dependent on natural forces.  What if the "natural Pacific decadal oscillation" or "variations in the Earth orbital element" (impressive words, ah?) will lead to climate changes that render the solar/wind/ocean/river energy sources ineffectual?  Long-term climate fluctuations show that it is not an "if" but a "when" question".  What will "the scientist" be campaigning for at this point?

text:
The thing about these long term changes is that we can see them coming and that they are much much slower. If the earths temperature change by 2 degrees over 10000 years, we can deal with that and adapt. If it changes more than 3 degrees over 200 years we're in a lot of trouble. We've set up our infrastructure for a world that is a degree colder, and temperatures are still rapidly rising. This is what's the danger, that houses we built  a few decades ago will get flooded, fields and wells we've been relying on will dry up before we can move to new water sources or set up new transport lines for food, that storms and wildfires destroy towns because we didn't know these areas would be at risk when they were settled, or that cities in the subtropics will simply become to hot to live there, never mind the fact that it's harder to supply them with food and water.
We can deal with all these changes, even very rapidly respond to them. For example the Netherlands have built an incredible dam system, but that is incredibly expensive. Climate change won't end human civilization, but it will force us to change a lot of the stuff to protect ourselves from these new problems. Divorcing fossile fuels and preventing emissions is simply the better deal. It's cheaper to build renewables now rather than fixing the damages later.
So with all of that, even if in 10000 years that climate has changed and the renewable plants we have now aren't as effective, because there'll never be a point where they aren't effective at all, the sun always shines, the wind always blows, if they aren't as effective well adapt because we have time to do so. Right now we don't have that time, or at least not without paying for it in trillions.
And just because this illustrates the point nicely. You expressed the worry of being dependent on these natural cycles, were already dependent on them. Coal and oil don't last forever. They were created by these cycles and everything that were digging up right now was once in the atmosphere. Now were putting it back an dealing with the subsequent consequences. In the end we're only accelerating these climate cycles and we're still dependent on them.
author: Xsomono

text: Â @XsomonoÂ  Good points to consider.  Cost/benefit too.  Although, you are generous on 10K years cycles: "Abrupt warming and gradual cooling oscillations during this period of Earthâ€™s history are known as Dansgaard-Oeschger cycles"  = "about 11,500 years ago, averaged annual temperatures on the Greenland ice sheet increased by around 8 Â°C over 40 years."  Humans in Sahara were wiped out by changing climate in the course of 1-2K years.  "Year 536"... - about "sun always shines".  The wind and hydro are not independent, but derivatives of the Sun energy.  I hope you don't assume my favoring coal and oil, but how did nuclear become an enemy of the climate worriers?  In any event.  Hundreds of interlinked (and costly) decisions are to be made.  One thing is clear: moving the temperature back where it was 100 years ago - is a misguided and impossible goal.
author: Igor Alexeev

text:
â€‹Â @Igor AlexeevÂ  I looked up the Dansgaard-Oeschger events and it seems like they really are pretty much completely natural events that we can't control in any meaningful way. If that sort of thing happens we just have to suck it up. But I don't see why renewables would be less useful than other forms of energy acquisition in that scenario. 
Either way, the main difference between those kinds of events and the scenario we are in right now is that we can prevent our climate from shifting. We have the control of and pretty much the sole responsibility for climate change. So we should definitely do something about it.

Does it makes sense though to use the term "wiped out" though when speaking about time spans of 1-2K years? Because I would argue we don't really care about that sort of stuff. That is the gradual change I talked about. In those case we can adapt and I imagine that's what the people who livied there did. After all, the probably didn't get on big drought and then all either die or flee elsewhere. They probably noticed over the course of generations that their fields yielded less and less, until some son decided not to follow the example of his parents and grandparents and simply decided to live and try his luck elsewhere. We can deal with that sort of thing. What we can't deal with is when these fields dry up in a single generation. 
Of course wind- and hydropower are ultimately also solar energy, but as you said, while they might change a bit, there'll always be a lot of direct solar energy to go around, which also means that there will still be wind and rivers. Maybe a wind power plant won't produce as much but that the wind will completely stop in that area is pretty unlikely. Renewable energy sources aren't as reliable as others means of generating power, because they can't be controlled as flexibly, but despite fluctuations you can still rely on them producing a lot of power.
When it comes to nuclear energy, I'm also very disappointed in the environmentalist movement for disavowing nuclear power. I live in Germany and about two decades past my country decided to phase out nuclear power. I think that was disastrous decision. To me it's clear that the fossil plants should have been turned of first. That being said, I'm not knowledgeable enough on the topic to say weather it's worth investing into new nuclear plants now. After all that sector is extremely expensive. I'm not clear on the question weather to prevent climate change it's better to simply invest into renewables now or if it makes sense to muster the huge funds necessary for investments in nuclear.

When it comes to changing the climate back to previous levels, I don't know of anyone who has that as their stated goal. I think the overwhelming majority in the climate movement would be ecstatic if the climate stayed exactly as it is now. It's mainly about stopping the trend to more warming rather than getting to a particular level. And right now it doesn't look like the warming trend will stop enough to prevent a pretty drastic shift in temperature. So I think the climate movement is absolutely necessary to get governments to act on climate protection, otherwise in a few decades we probably will end up with trillions in damages world wide because of the temperature shift .
author: Xsomono

text: Â @XsomonoÂ  I am with you on most points.  I only hope the campaigners will not loose sight of billions spent to prevent billions of damages, and quality of life sacrificed to protect quality of environment.  :)
author: Igor Alexeev

text:
Â @Igor AlexeevÂ  To be honest, I think very few people actually care about the environment, I certainly don't. We can't really destroy the environment anyways. Even if humans destroy millions of species there'll just be new ones, nature goes on, it's really only about protecting the parts of the environment we rely on. The only reason I want to preserve it is because a lower quality of environment would decrease the quality of life. And with everything going on I'm throwing my hat in the ring with the climate movement and also support the sentiment, that it's worth spending a lot of money on and enduring a lot of painful structural change because of climate protection policies because the extreme power we have over the planet to me really is frightening. From where we stand now it looks like humans will ultimately singlehandedly melt the Arctic ice cap. That will be trillions of tons of ice. I think risk of such powerful effects destroying things we rely on like sources of food and water are simply to great. But the concern you have is of course a reasonable one.
This was a great conversation though, it's very easy to get angry at each other over the internet, so thank you for this. Merry Christmas while we are ar it.
author: Xsomono

text: Indeed, not all science is. Mechanical engineering for example and computer science don't need govt funding to stay afloat because they're a genuine high impact field in societal transformation and evolution, as well as being tangibly applicable Climate science, on the other hand needs to justify its existence and funding via less consensual means (the taxpayer) by sensationalizing the warming trends to the nth degree. The senator, albeit ineloquently attempts to allude to historical trends of warming that have been occurring since the Little Ice Age of the 1700s as well as previous trends throughout the millennia, since well before we consumed carbon at the level we do. Furthermore, there are other legitimate objections to the "negativity" that anthropogenic climate change poses to the biosphere, one being that vegetation has never been more fruitful in aggregate around the globe, despite deforestation (which is not desirable, I'll point out). Another objection being, is that the activity of the star we orbit has a much bigger impact on the warming trends than the state of gaseous carbon in our atmosphere as we are supposedly due for the most impactful solar minimum in centuries as well as other potential game changing climate events. Our carbon "taxes" and Paris Climate Accords are posturing and nothing else.

text:
Â @thinkof2morrowÂ  First, global warming didn't become climate change. Global warming is exactly what it sounds like, the planet's temperature rising. Climate change includes global warming, but also includes rising sea levels, glacier reduction, intensity in extreme weather occurrences (earthquakes, tornados, hurricanes), etc. The change in phrasing throughout the scientific community is because we're talking about multiple issues, not just temperature.

Second, saying that conservatives use logic and science, while simultaneously saying scientists can't be trusted...what? 97% of the scientific community agrees climate change is a threat to humanity. To argue that would be akin of being diagnosed with cancer by 97 doctors, only to find 3 who would disagree, 2 of which are probably funded by Dupont or Phillip Morris, and the other just not good at his job.

Third, the US contributes 1 of every 25 deaths in this country to air pollution. The US contributes (as of 2017) 14% of CO2 emissions, despite having less than 5% of the global population. The US needs to move off of fossil fuels, and listening to Ron Johnson, who in 2010 received $400,000 in money from the Oil and Gas sector argue with a scientist who spent much of his career working for NASA, then pursued education in the Earth's climate, is appalling, and furthermore, disingenuous.

What completely kills me is, this has been known since 1988, and still conservative law makers let oil money come before science. It's great that cars are more gas efficient, but any time we talk about green energy, conservatives lose their minds.

text:

author: Nathan Christensen

text:
Â @Nathan ChristensenÂ  The earth has without a doubt gone through regular climate cycles and is continuing to do so. The primary difference between past cycles and the current one, though, is the rate of change of co2 concentrations and associated temperature. The simple kind of "series of events" and questions that have led to our current understanding of climate is something like this: 

Climate is warming. Why? Well there are natural cycles in solar insolation, earth wobble, orbital eccentricities etc. Well, we tested those ideas and found that changes in astral sources of warming don't explain all of the variability in temperature. So there's likely a source here on Earth. Researchers then turned to ice cores, tree rings, fossils, formanifera, and other long term natural record keepers and found that atmospheric co2 seemed to track climate extensively. They found co2 levels and temperature have fluctuated wildly before human beings even had axes.

Okay, so co2 is associated with temperature. Are we just in a natural cycles of co2 fluctuation then? This is where we are currently at; the answer is maybe but probably no. Recent rates of co2 concentration increase and associated warming are much higher than observed over previous natural cycles. This is where many of the current complex "ensemble" models come from. Now we are using models of movement of energy and radiative forcing to try to understand the sources and consequences of co2 and other greenhouse gas emmissions, and all models point to an anthropogenic source that far outpaces natural variation. 

This is not to say that natural cycles still aren't occurring. We are simply exacerbating a natural change. 

There's very few conservatives that deny climate change entirely. They are just asking the scientific and economic question of: What % of blame are human beings at fault given the data on thousands of years of average global temperature and what can we do about it within the bounds of money?

https://shepherdgazette.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/07/youngerdryas-holocene.jpg

author: Nathan Christensen

text: Â @Nathan ChristensenÂ  In the past, kings and priests told peasants what to believe... today "approved science" experts tell people what to believe. Power rules... and power decides what scholars say.
author: Howard Phillips

text:
Â @Howard PhillipsÂ  You're still appealing to an authoritative rhetorical framework. 

I think you're confusing authority for expertise. The difference is very important.

Given our human condition, we ALL have to trust someone about something based solely of their communication and demonstration of ideas. The issue is not that we DO trust the ideas of other humans. The issue is WHY and HOW do we trust the ideas of other humans. 

Could the science of human caused climate change be a power ploy by political elite AND be legitimately accurate science? Are they mutually exclusive?

Could human caused climate change be accurate science AND the political efforts to reverse it be in good faith? Could that also not rhetorically be the case?

So we're still back to the original question. How could you know?? Seems to me the first step in answering that question would be to temporarily and deliberately abandon your ideological apprehensions and conduct effortful investigation of the science (without any ideological destination in mind). If the findings are legitimate then they should stand up to detailed scrutiny and expert analysis. 

After you answer the expertise question with some measure of confidence THEN you can move on to the messier authoritarian question that is, "what should we do about it?"
author: Nathan Christensen

text:
Â @Nathan ChristensenÂ  People have the right to trust or not trust by their choosing. Nobody has the right to impose authority of trust.

You keep attributing me with some kind of "ideology". I don't like to respond to "ad hominem" attacks, but seems that is necessary now.

I don't like politics in general. I was not defending that senator (I don't know him nor his party). I am a big defender of nature and ecologist by heart. I believe human activities has a big impact in the planet climate. But I don't believe the current agenda propaganda, and I have my reasons. I will not impose my thinking unto others, and I ask that you don't impose your thinking unto me. 

 If you want to be clean with the ecosystem, you should know I want the same, and therefore you have all my support. 

But if you want to establish a totalitarian "ecologist regime", then you have found a new enemy.
author: Howard Phillips

text:
Â @Howard PhillipsÂ  This is a discussion in the comments of a YT video. If this qualifies as "imposing" for you then maybe you should examine your own rhetorical sensitivities.

And yes, we are all entitled to believe what we want. But we're not entitled to how those beliefs align with reality.

I'm glad to hear that you accept the scientific findings that support human caused climate change. But if you're apprehensive about ecological totalitarianism maybe you should do some effortful investigation into the system we currently live in. Who is pushing the boogeyman of ecological totalitarianism and what are their financial interests? What percentage of economic totalitarianism do we already have?

Also, FYI, I am personally pro-nuclear power as a potential solution to this global issue. I see very strong evidence that the "green" renewable energy solutions are being pushed by the mega corps that got us into this mess in the first place.

text:

text:
Â @Howard PhillipsÂ  Sigh Ok, we're back to square one here so I guess we're done. 

Unless of course you can justify your claim about scientific manipulation with a preponderance of direct evidence. Your appeal to conspiratorial thinking is sexy but it rings hollow in the grand scope of scientific rigor.

I want to follow good evidence to the most likely truth. I'm willing to portion my belief to the weight of the evidence if it can be reliably demonstrated. If you have such evidence please deliver it. Otherwise, your claims might sound appealing (and guard your ego from accepting an uncomfortable reality) but they are unjustified by rational analysis.


(And what the hell is "the scientific academy"?)

text:

Similar effects do not necessarily indicate similar causes. We have to examine individual mechanisms and the details of the processes to get a complete picture. And we must be willing to go where the evidence takes us.

text: Â @Dudley BurlesonÂ  Thatâ€™s not exactly how that works. Scientists donâ€™t just huddle together and come out with a consensus. They publish peer reviewed papers that are available even to the general public. Also, it is a highly competitive field where they are always competing for jobs, and grants. They love to be the one to shoot down competitors and have the stand out paper that changes the game. If your peers canâ€™t shoot your paper down your sitting pretty. Itâ€™s at the point where no one can shoot things down that your paper becomes part of the consensus. Science is complex but opinions arenâ€™t a part of it, only data and science.
author: ElLenadorLA

text:
Â @Dudley BurlesonÂ  No, you have no idea how science works. The biggest goal of scientists is to prove the other wrong. That is called peer review. It is the safeguard against false conclusions. 
If some scientist can prove that climate change today is not increasingly made worse because of human activity, other scientists will accept that and that person will win prizes.
When 97% of scientists agree, and 3% disagree, the chance that the 97% are wrong, is extremely unlikely. Climate change has been investigated for over a century now. Not by 1 group of scientists, but by thousands of scientists of different universities and the majority of countries around the world. 
Are the above scrutiny? Absolutely not. They are under constant scrutiny by other scientists.
If 3% of scientists would claim that the Earth is flat, would you claim that 97% is wrong and that 97% is in on some conspiracy? 
It is clear that you don't know the scientific process. 
I have done scientific research for years at a university in Belgium. The biggest goal was for me to prove my results to be wrong. It is what scientists do. Trying to prove your own hypothesis wrong. If you can't prove it wrong, then the hypothesis keeps standing as the most likely explanation. Then those results get reviewed by peers. If they find any error, then the hypothesis is not accepted and will not graduate into a theory.

text:
what he said was "...the time in the season at wich its closest to the sun"
let me explain it to you: currently the earth is closest to the sun during northern winter. that means while the sun rays arive at a greater angle (wich is the dominant factor for surface temperatures and seasons) the solar input is greater. that way your winter is a little warmer than normal and your summer is a little colder than normal. a warmer winter means less snow/ice coverage and less snow means less sun ray reflection (albedo effect), wich results in a warming effect.
its important to note that it also has positive effects on the vegetation in both seasons, wich partially counteracts this warming effect due to photosynthesis. 
those factors only play a role in global climate because the landmasses are not equally distributed between the two hemispheres. (around 70% of the landmasses are in the northern hemisphere)

text: This question is quite polarizing, especially in the US, it seems. One interesting thing is that nature does not care about opinions. Nature just goes about its' business, and the laws of physics does not change based on someone's opinion. This leads to the conclusion that two opposing beliefs about what happens in nature cannot both be true. Therefore, we need a method to investigate - with as much objectivity as possible (removing as much human bias as possible) - what is more likely to be true. And we already have such a method. It's been very successful though not perfect - it's a process / in development - but it's the best we've got at the moment.

text: Anthony Purcell so is the earth cooling or warming?
author: Oldsole guidry

text:
Â @Oldsole guidryÂ  over the past 150 years Earth's global mean surface temperature has risen. That warming is ongoing.

To discuss trends in global mean surface temperature on interannual timescales is meaningless. Such variations are stochastic.

When discussing climate it is usual to do so only with respect to timescales of 30 years or longer.
author: PhD Tony

text:
Â @Oldsole guidryÂ  it is also helpful to use terminology with some degree of accuracy. Rather than talking about Earth "warming" you need to specify more precisely what you mean.

Earth's global mean surface temperature is very different from Earth's effective emission temperature (the temperature at which Earth radiates energy to space). The difference between these two quantities is actually very large.

Which quantity are you referring to?
author: PhD Tony

text: Anthony Purcell let's start with the term global warming.  How are we warming?
author: Oldsole guidry

text:
Â @Oldsole guidryÂ  Having already told you to be more precise with your terminology you instantly use a loosely defined term.

Global mean surface temperature (GMST) has risen over the past 150 years because of the addition of CO2 to the atmosphere due to burning of fossil fuels.

How does atmospheric CO2 impact surface temperature?

To answer that question I am going to have to teach you some physics.

Let's start with conservation of energy. The Earth must re-radiate the energy it receives from the sun. We can measure the energy Earth receives from the sun and then use the Stefan-Boltzmann law to calculate Earth's effective emission temperature.

Doing so we obtain a value of 255 K = -18 C = 0 F. This theoretical value was confirmed by satellite observations in the 1960s.

But if you look out your window you will see Earth is not frozen. In fact Earth's GMST is ~288 K = 15 C = 59 F. The difference of 33 C was noted in 1827.

You can also work out something weird is going on by looking at the Moon. Why is the lunar surface so much colder (on average) than Earth's?

It took about two seconds for people to suggest that the fact Earth has an atmosphere and the moon doesn't might play a role. The question was: how?

We have already seen a big clue. If you were high above Earth and pointed an IR telescope at Earth the reading you obtained would NOT be surface temperature. The upper atmosphere masks the surface. The same is true for Venus - the IR readings from Earth are very different from Venus's actual surface temperature.

The opacity of the atmosphere to IR is reflected in the atmosphere's optical thickness. You can only see one optical thickness into the atmosphere.

However, the temperature at that altitude is fixed at 255 K.

Now we can answer the initial question. If you add CO2 to the atmosphere you make it optically thicker. So the emission altitude moves higher - closer to the top of the atmosphere. But in the troposphere temperature increases as altitude decreases. So moving the emission altitude higher increases surface temperature.

Any questions?
author: PhD Tony

text: Anthony Purcell I didn't see you earlier post.  So you are saying that a rise in CO2 causes a direct rise in Temperature.  Am I correct?
author: Oldsole guidry

text: Anthony Purcell also the reason I used a "loosely defined term" is because politicians and especially climate scientist use this same loose term.  And you are 100% correct, it is a very loose term.  Might be why most people are skeptical.  You are the 1st person to explain your position with Any science.  But since we have had 800x's the co2 as we do now during the last ice age it is very muddy to believe.  Bottom line, there needs to be better representation from your side to get the fact across because it's mostly political rhetoric.
author: Oldsole guidry

text:
Â @Oldsole guidryÂ  Yes, there were much higher CO2 concentrations during snowball Earth phases such as the Makganyene.

You seem not to understand the significance of this. The fact Earth is not trapped in a snowball state is due entirely to CO2.

During a snowball event albedo is much higher so nearly all solar energy is reflected to space. Also, there is very little water vapour available. So such phases are very cold and tend to stay cold.

The only mechanism that can break Earth out of a snowball event is volcanic outgassing of CO2 - which is VERY slow.

Also, we know there was liquid water on Earth's surface 4 billion years ago when the sun was 30% dimmer. This is called the "Faint young sun paradox" and the solution again is the greenhouse effect.

You can find detailed discussions of these observations and many others in any textbook on planetary climate.

I will also draw your attention to the fact that one of the major tests of CO2 radiative forcing was observations of Venus. The person who undertook the modelling that best matched the observations was one Carl Sagan.

Your assertion that climate scientists are inept and imprecise is fatuous drivel born of near complete ignorance.
author: PhD Tony

text:
Â @Oldsole guidryÂ  Your question is ill-posed.


Are all other parameters held fixed?
On what time-scale is the enhanced CO2 level imposed?
Are you talking about regional temperature or global mean? Are you talking about surface temperature or temperature at altitude? If so, what altitude?


Temperature is impacted by many factors, these parameters include but are not limited to:


albedo


solar energy output (which varies slightly on decadal and centennial time-scales but changes massively on time-scales of billions of years).


precession angle, orbital eccentricity, obliquity (which vary on time-scales of thousands of years)


other greenhouse concentrations (water vapour, methane etc.)


aerosol concentration


continental configuration (which varies on time-scales of millions of years)


Radiative forcing is measured in W/m^2. 1 Watt = 1 Joule per second. So the amount of energy entering the system depends on how long the radiative forcing is applied.  Brief changes in CO2 concentration (as are observed on seasonal or diurnal time-scales) are not able to change Earth's energy balance sufficiently to influence global temperature.


I would ask that you stop asking vague questions and engage in this discussion in good faith. If you think you have a counterexample present it.
author: PhD Tony

text:
Â @Oldsole guidryÂ  What I find singularly disingenuous is that you clearly haven't read any textbooks on this issue and if you have read any journal articles they are a pretty limited selection. But you hold climate scientists responsible because you are not being spoon-fed.


Here is a link to a textbook on climate science:


https://www.cambridge.org/gb/academic/subjects/earth-and-environmental-science/climatology-and-climate-change/principles-planetary-climate?format=HB&isbn=9780521865562


Fair warning: It's over 600 pages long and you're going to need graduate level physics and mathematics to fully comprehend it.


There are two possibilities:


1) You do have the skills needed to read and digest this book - in which case I encourage you to do so.
2) You do not have the skills needed to read and digest this book - in which case I encourage you to limit your pronouncements on climate change to requests for information.

author: Gustav

text:
Â @PhD TonyÂ  This question is quite polarizing, especially in the US, it seems. I think maybe one way forward is to bring the discussion to the fundamental subject of truth and facts. We know that nature does not care about opinions. The laws of physics does not change based on someone's opinion. Anyone who will subscribe to this fact could also realize that two opposing beliefs about what happens in nature cannot both be true. After agreeing on that, we can start talking about methods of gaining knowledge about what's really happening in nature. We can agree that we need a method with as much objectivity as possible (removing as much human bias as possible). With that established in our conversation, we can learn that science applies such a method. We can talk about the scientific method and why it's important, it's strengths and limitations.

Just my five cents on the subject. I think it's important for every scientist to think about strategies for how to communicate and interact with non-scientists. Anyhow, I realize that in some cases it will be impossible to reach the common ground required for a fruitful conversation of the sorts suggested above.
author: Gustav

More data are available, but the trajectory of warming has not changed.
author: R C

text:
Â @Dudley BurlesonÂ  you do know they were actually quite correct.
There is this misleading quote that is used a lot by these anti climate change groups, namely that the prediction is wrong in a famous paper. But what they do not tell you is that it was one of 3 scenarios. They do not tell you that one of them was almost completely correct.

Basically he predicted the tempersture to go up in all models so no matter whoch it would go up. But the rate dependent on some parameters and one of them was not very well understood at the time. So he made three scenarios (what if that parameter had this value).

But the funny thing is, even if all models would be off then still the measuremenrs remain. The measurements show temperature rising. If someone tells you each year it gets 1 degree hotter but then you experience it gets 10 degrees hotter each year. Will you then also say? Ahh we dont have to take this heat serious because you said 1 degree and it is actually way worse. (Ofcourse these were exegeratted numbers, i am not claiming temperature each year rises this much, we would all be dead in a matter of 1 or 2 years if that was the case)

text:
That is an incredibely stupid attitude, sorry to say. Basically scientists, who work through the scientific method, have come to the conclusion that mankind is currently the most important factor when it comes to climate change. For decades politicians have largely ignored this, catering to lobbyists from fossil fuel industries and have refusing to take adequate measures to counteract the extent of the human factor.

Now, when the evidence for human influence on climate change is higher than ever and the timeframe for us to somewhat effectively change this is smaller and growing smaller, politicians have started to realize it's perhaps better to act accordingly, rather than to cater to the wants of a specific industry, for temporary financial and economic gain. And as a response you go "the government wants me to believe man-made climate change is real? Must be some sort of conspiracy.". Why dont you realize that the conspiracy is on the side of those denying the human factor? You know, the side that is funded by, and acting in the interests of the largest and most influential industry on the planet.

text:
well it has been a month so i dont think i will get an answer if i wait. so i will just answer both questions so that people going threw this threat can keep up
first your question: "do you think people have the power to change the climate?"

yes, i do think people have the power to change the climate. for the last 10000 years CO2 levels where stable between 260ppm and 280ppm. since the beginn of industrial carbon emissions the CO2 concentration increased to 400ppm without any change of natural parameters. that means that currently over 1/3 of the CO2 in the Atmosphere is anthropogenic.
h2O(water) CH4(methane) and CO2 have the ability to absorb thermal infrared radiation, wich delays re-radiation to space and results in warming inside the atmosphere. this effect is called the green house effect and became an observable fact in 1969 with the Nimbus 3 satellite data. (it is good, that the greenhouse gases exist, without them our global surface temperature would be -18Â°C on average according to the Stefan-Boltzmann law)
since humans caused an increase in CO2 in the atmosphere, and since CO2 is a greenhouse gas, humans are responsible for the increasing temperatures since 1850. thats the short and simplified version.

now to my question "can you evaluate what mistake johnson did there when he said "so those variations just end right now, so its all man made?"
he ignores the time needed for those variations to occur. (a one word answer with "time" or "time scale" or "time needed" would have been enough for me)
the orbital elements of the earth cycle in ten thousands of years. those variations dont stop, but if you only observe them for a few decades, they will appear to be constant and will not have any impact on the climate.

text:
Dr. Hansen has been an extreme activist and has invested his entire career into dire predictions about global warming. To date, his predictions have been dramatically inaccurate throughout his career. He predicted a rise in sea level of as much as 10 meters per century. I believe that he made this prediction in 2004, which would indicate that the seas should have risen 1.4 meters by now.  According to National Geographic website, they have risen 10-20 centimeters. 

Dr. Hansen proposes carbon taxes while admitting this would only mitigate the problem. Of course, such proposals don't consider the negative impact to US and world economies resulting in lower research funding and perhaps less opportunity for a technological solution that could actually solve the problem.

Dr. Hansen has written extensively in favor of nuclear fuels. His writings were challenged by reputable scientists as using data that was "incomplete and misleading" and "lacking credibility".

Dr. Hansen's assertion that "the man-made effect is now dominate" is disputed by many reputable climatologists.

Political activists like Hansen create chaos with exaggerated claims. They throw gasoline on a dispute that is already burning out of control. We need reason, not inflammatory rhetoric. We need non-political scientists and economists to provide well reasoned information and, if necessary, alternative solutions, preferably scientific, not political, solutions.

text: This question is quite polarizing, especially in the US, it seems. One interesting thing is that nature does not care about opinions. Nature just goes about its' business, and the laws of physics does not change based on someone's opinion. This leads to the conclusion that two opposing beliefs about what happens in nature cannot both be true. Therefore, we need a method to investigate - with as much objectivity as possible (removing as much human bias as possible) - what is more likely to be true. And we already have such a method. It's been very successful though not perfect - it's a process / in development - but it's the best we've got at the moment.

text:
One of these men has devoted his career in understanding the science. The other is a politician, who doesn't have the time to understand the science, and more alarmingly chooses not to trust the scientist, but his own quick recearch about the matter.

You make the age old claim that "climate has always been changing and it always will, no man was doing it before man kind, why would they now" 

If you would only listen and read the explanations that you are provided. The science is there in textbooks. Studies can be found online. If you feel lazy and just want to watch videos, you can watch potholer54's videos about climate change.

No one has ever denied that climate has been changing over the centuries and millenia. Climate changes due to milankovitch cycles (vobble in the earts orbit around the sun), solar irradiance (changes in suns activity) etc. Only thing is that milankovitch cycles are so slow that they are happening slowly in thousands of years. There is also no exceptionally active period in suns activity currently, that would have a direct correlation in earths gradual warming. What we do have is burning fossil fuels, releasing the Co2 in the atmosphere, which will slowly start to pile up. Piling up of Co2 in the atmosphere causes more suns energy to be trapped in atmosphere instead of radiating into space, this causes gradual heating etc. Its 1.37am here so im not going to write more about the matter, go do your own recearch. Basic facts should be correct in what I wrote.

author: Joe Shmo

text:
The evidence for the fact that greenhouse gas emissions change the climate is uncontraverted. The evidence for the fact that greenhouse gas emissions are a principal cause in current warming trends is accepted by the overwhelming majority of experts. The people who don't yet accept the theory don't for many reasons, including ignorance and propaganda. Most younger generations, however, accept the facts, which suggests that popular opinion will change as the ill-informed die off or become more informed. It's no accident that climate change went from a fringe view among the general public to the prevailing view of experts and nations around the world in just a few decades.

The people who need the most convincing right now are the GOP leadership, and even they are changing their tune. Kasich and Rubio both took more moderated positions in 2016 than they had before.

Desertification certainly aggravates the speed of climate change but it's far from a principal cause.

text:
See 'Atmospheric CO2: Principal Control Knob Governing Earthâ€™s Temperature' by Andrew A. Lacis, Gavin A. Schmidt, David Rind, Reto A. Rued for an example of a leading study on the greenhouse effect on Earth. For a more general source on the greenhouse effect per se I recommend the astrophysical research on Venus' atmosphere because it's a case study in the greenhouse effect run amok.

I now see that your view is so out of step with scientific consensus that I don't think the onus is on me to change it here. You've both offered no substantial evidence for your view and asserted that the vast majority of experts are wrong -- that's a hill for you to climb, not me. If you've an issue with the enormous scientific agreement about the role of gas emissions in global warming then take it up with NASA and the American National Academy of Sciences. "Connective oils" is not, at this stage, a credible view compared to the gas model, which is already supported by decades of research, popular support, global initiatives, and political support. If you've some credible peer reviewed sources that support your view over the gas model I'd be happy to see them.

text:
Why would there ever be a standstill or a slow down in the climates increase?  I mean, I imagine the co2 emissions have continued to rise at probably an exponential rate. A standstill would only make sense if we somehow managed to reduce emissions - but the truth is quite the contrary to this.  Even as I'm writing this message co2 is being emitted at a rate of"2 736 000 tons/hour".  That's  23.9 trillion tons or 2.39x10^15 kg of co2 being emitted a year. So how many trillions of tons of co2 emissions are required to make the temperature increase at a rate that is apocalyptic in proportion?   

Truth be told, there are many other variables driving the climate-  variables that are much bigger (like the main source of warmth for our planet the sun).  The fact that they're constantly pushing this theory of climate change in the media and presenting it in such a myopic manner only reinforces my feeling that this is more a political fear monger campaign used with ulterior motives driving it- then it is an actual scientific analysis.

Just in case someone doesn't know the answers to the questions the senator asks, the natural cycles have always changed our climate, but that happens on the time scale of tens of thousands of years, and sometimes centuries, but never decades. The warming "hiatus" is only present in the data of you take 98 as the starting year, which is deceptive, as it was a really warm El Nino year, so it looks like the curve is flattening out. This is NOT  unexplained, it is rather obvious when you look at the whole data set.

text:
Nobody is denying that the climate is changing or the human effect on climate. Even the senator concurs with that. The issue is if human activity is the principle cause of it and if we should change our behaviour. Not to save the environment but to save ourselves. 

Mr. Hansen states that rising temps are a function of elements like "time in the season where it's closest to the sun" and "energy coming in than going out". Yet if you look at all the models the IPCC has used, they greatly discount the sun as a factor for weather and indeed climate. 30+ years of bogus modeling and junk science driven by a political agenda. That's what this is. The pause in temps is because our star is entering it's grand minimum for this cycle and there's generally less radiation coming off it. We are on the precipice of an ice age and people are not prepared for it.

For example, at 0:38 Hansen tries to assert the PDO explains a 16 year "pause" in global warming (it is now up to 20 years). Umm, no. PDOs do not last for decades.Try again. Oh, and Hansen did try many times over the past 20 years to come up with some ad hoc explanation. He failed with every attempt.

Again, at 2:00 Hansen tries to assert the warming experienced 10,000 years ago, which took us out of the last Ice Age, was due to orbital mechanics. Umm, no. Orbital mechanics investigated by Milutin Milankovic more than 100 years ago is insufficient to explain why levels of CO2 at 5000ppmv did not keep us warm. Three of the last 10 deglaciation periods occurred while earth's eccentricity was decreasing from its maximum, and two of the last 10 deglaciation periods occurred while earth's eccentricity was a minimum. So fully 50% of the last 10 deglaciations do not fit the theory. In science we call this a "lack of correlation". Look it up. Pure chance has an equally good result as to why glaciations and deglaciations have occurred over the past 10 climate cycles. This is why mainstream science ignored Milankovic's theory until about 1976, which immediately preceded Hansen's campaign to convince the world we must stop using fossil fuels. In other words, the sudden increase in interest in Milankovic's dead theory had nothing to do with science, and everything to do with concocting a case against humanity to blame us for causing global warming. 

Doubt this? Svante Arrhenius was also discredited by his peers, leaving his theory about a trace gas in earth's atmosphere languishing until the 1980s. Then pseudoscientists (like Hansen) who were studying climate ignored 60 years of established climate science to begin popularizing Arrhenius's idea (it wasn't a theory, because it wasn't developed sufficiently to qualify). The liars were counting on years of cleaning out libraries to bury the evidence against Milankovic and Arrhenius so that their false climate models would withstand criticism by all but the most persistent research scientists, and these could be easily dismissed and discredited as a "fringe element" by those in control of the scientific journals and major organizations.

The problem? The pseudoscientists went too far in their predictions, and more real scientists started to take notice. Now that every global climate model based on warming due to the increase in CO2 has been fully discredited, and the idea of warming due to a tiny increase in a trace gas in earth's atmosphere has been debunked, the pseudoscientists like Hansen are running around like Chicken Little screaming, "The planet is warming, the planet is warming!" They aren't doing any more science, they are attempting to silence their critics.

This is not science. Scientists never attempt to silence critics. Fascists do that, and fascism is a Leftist tool to gain and consolidate power.

text: You know why I can't get on board with the climate change folks?Â  Because they are hypocrites.Â  They preach how much we need to go reusable and green.Â  It's their mantra.Â  They hammer us over the head with it.Â  And then they totally ignore their own argument.Â  Caser in point.Â  I had the displeasure of having to spend two weeks in Cali at the beginning of Oct.Â  While driving from Mojave to the Central Valley, I noticed all the windmills in farms along 58.Â  Hundreds of them.Â  All over the place.Â  On a pretty breezy day.Â  And no more than 10% of them were turning.Â  Driving back 2 weeks later, same thing.Â  Good air, and maybe 25% of them were turning.Â  Ran through Texas on the way back.Â  No more windy that it was in Cali.Â  All the windmills they have along 40?Â  Hundreds of them...turning.Â  Same in Oklahoma.Â  Windmills out the wazoo...ALL turning!Â  Last time I checked, TX and OK were "conservative", "Republican" climate change denying states...yet, they were outperforming the eat, drink, and crap GREEN holier than thou Cali, wind farms by a ton!Â  Greenies, you want people to join you?Â  Then perform!Â  Running your mouths alone...justÂ doesn't cut it anymore.

text: This question is quite polarizing, especially in the US, it seems. One interesting thing is that nature does not care about opinions. Nature just goes about its' business, and the laws of physics does not change based on someone's opinion. This leads to the conclusion that two opposing beliefs about what happens in nature cannot both be true. Therefore, we need a method to investigate - with as much objectivity as possible (removing as much human bias as possible) - what is more likely to be true. And we already have such a method. It's been very successful though not perfect - it's a process / in development - but it's the best we've got at the moment.

text:
A difference of 0.1 degrees Fahrenheit in the entire roughly 5000 millions of millions of tons of atmosphere, may seem a trifling amount of heat. But the sun shines upon three or four times as much ocean as it does land. 
That same  0.1 degrees F difference in all the planet's oceanic water is a very significant amount, and accounts for some of what Hansen calls the inertia of the system.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
"Climate Change" is misleading and possibly pusillanimous. A prefix of "Drastic" or "Disastrous" would make the point better.
But although "Anthropogenic Global Warming" can be exposed to the trivial objection "Well it's not happening here", it is more totally accurate, and James Hansen in one particular sentence made it clear.
Human conversion of fossil carbon sequestered by the Carboniferous period, consuming oxygen from the same origin, to make the persistent infrared-absorbing CO2, is changing the rate at which the planet can radiate as much energy outwards as is coming in. 
It is therefore retaining daily enough of the prodigious solar radiation to which the oceans especially are exposed, that overall it is retaining more heat. That is Global Warming.
Weather prediction is fiendishly difficult, climate predictions almost as bad (or maybe worse). But the global sum of radiation in and out is comparatively easy.
People whose idea of climate is merely historical are hampered even to understand that the planet's atmosphere for 3500 million years was nothing at all like ours. Physicists, chemists, and  biologists generally believe that the oxygen in the atmosphere is a product of photosynthesis and tectonic burial of drowned vegetation, as are the fossil carbon and hydrocarbon fuels. That immense change took somewhat more than 60 million years.
Before that, there was a time when the chief "greenhouse" gas was methane at a concentration  of tens of ppm, not the hundreds of ppm of today's CO2. CH4 has a much stronger effect.
author: Albert Rogers

author: Jonathan Lindgren

text: Ronan carbon dioxide exists at roughly 400 molicules per million molicules of all other gasses in our atmosphere. Historically co2 has helped regulate the temperature of the Earth's crust by retaining the heat of the Sun as it passes through our atmosphere and reflects off the Earth's surface. As co2 levels in our atmosphere increase more of the sun's heat is trapped, warming the planet. This effect helped end the last major ice age. co2 is not dangerous, in fact it's good for the planet as it helps maintain a steady atmospheric temperature. What's bad for the planet and many of the species that call it home is a change in the ppm. This change as explained above will warm (or cool if the ppm were in the reverse and falling) the planet and force thousands of less adaptable species to the brink of extinction. The ppm of co2 in the atmosphere has been recorded for hundreds of thousands of years through the clever use of onstage air pockets from ice samples across the globe. we can see the natural rise and fall of co2 in the atmosphere and compare it's effects with what the planet was going through environmentally and geologically at the time. An example being the end of the last ice age as I mentioned earlier. what isn't natural is the rate of ppm increase over the last hundred years, where we have seen a massive increase in atmospheric co2. Hope this helps to explain the importance of maintaining a steady co2 ppm average globally, and the effects on the planet should we fail to do so.
author: Aaron Daines

text:
Yes, I can! In the early 1950's scientists took the work of one G.S. Callendar, who speculated 30 years prior that the rising co2 levels in the earth's atmosphere was the cause of a warming global average temperature. These scientists through studies and experiments of their own (which are very well documented and easily searchable online) helped them prove Callendar's 30 year old prediction. Callendar wasn't the first to speculate that c02 in the earth's atmosphere could effect the climate however. In Victorian England, a small group of scientists gained an unfortunate reputation for suggesting that the carbon from human industry could one day lead to a rising global temperature. The effects of c02 in the atmosphere have been studied and recorded by humans for a long time.
That's the history behind the notion that c02 is 'bad' - which I'd like to point out is false. In nature there is no such thing as good or bad, asÂ the idea of something being better than something elseÂ is a humanÂ concept not a natural law. The same can be said for the planets 'health.' The health of the planet is judged by how healthy the planet is for us (humans and other species) to live on in relative comfort. So for the sake of my reply I'm going to refrain from using these sorts of concepts and stick, as you have to numbers.
You mentioned the earth once had an atmosphere of nearly 4000 ppm of c02. I assume to don't have an issue with the way this number was acquired through drilling into Antarctic ice like many who challenge the science behind global warming. Through the use of geological surveying we can observe that during this time of high atmospheric c02 concentration that the earth was experiencing heavy volcanic activity, and had been for some considerable time. This was before the last great ice age. In fact, so much ash was launched into the atmosphere that it blocked a majority of the suns light, giving birth to said ice age.The long and the short of it is, I can verify why adding c02 into the earth's atmosphere has an effect. Linking all of my resources here however would take far too long and I think rather spoil the joy of discussion. Instead I ask that if this is something you find interesting, you fact-check my statements in your own time and come back with your own findings, be they in agreement with what I say or not. The earth does have natural cycles. You and I agree on this, as we agreeÂ levels of c02 change throughout earths history. What I would like to bring attention to is the increasing c02 levels is not bad for the planet. It's bad for us.
author: Aaron Daines

author: Sweet Kicker

text:
Â @Sweet KickerÂ  in this case it became political because you, for no apparent reason, brought up the GND - a fringe climate change proposal from one wing of one party in one country.  I was simply pointing out that's exactly what it is so I wouldn't lose too much sleep over that particular proposal.

Now, I'm beginning to suspect you're trolling me because you appear to be acting deliberately obtuse.  Scientists are crystal clear on what the climate would look like if we mitigate climate change because the *climate wouldn't change*.  If you want to know how many hurricanes we'd get on average each year or what the global mean temperature would be, you just need to look up what they are now.  

If you're curious about what it looks like if we are less successful at mitigating climate change there are numerous papers you can find online analyzing outcomes for different scenarios based on exactly how much warming we get - 1C, 1.5C, and 2C are the most common.

If it is still unclear to you how preventing climate change simply means things stay roughly the same, by definition, I need you to explain in more detail exactly where the disconnect is for you.

text:
Â @NeverSettleForMediocrityÂ  The ratio of 13C/12C in the atm is decreasing which definitely indicates that the main problem is the burning of fossil fuels. The ratio of C14 to C12 is also decreasing which also indicates the use of fossil fuels. Since the rate of decay -(d[A]/dt) has been experimentally determined to be proportional to the amount of substance at any point in time we can derive an equation from this 
-dA/dt=kA 
We can then transpose then integrate within the boundaries [0,t]
-dA/A=kdt 
-|dA/A=k|dt 
ln(A0)-ln(A)=kt 

ln(A0/A)=kt 
ln(A/A0)=-kt
A/A0=e^-kt 
A=A0e^-kt 
Where A is the amount of substance at any point in time and A0 is the amount of substance before decay i.e when t=0 

As we can see it t is VERY large the amount of substance is VERY small. Virtually there will be no C14 left after a large amount of time has passed within fossils. However C14 is always replenished in the atmosphere so the ratio there stays relatively constant. 

Fossil fuels are usually aliphatic C molecules as a result when the combust in the presence of oxygen they will produce CO2 
CnH2n+2 + O2 ----> nCO2 + (n+1)H2O

However we've already established that C-14/C-12 ratio is lower in fossil fuels thus it will be higher in C12 in the form of CO2. 

As the amount of C-14 stays constant in the atm and the C12 increases the C-14/C-12 will obviously drop. This is what we see. 

The same is true of the C13/C12 ratio drop. 

Honestly this isnt rocket science at all.

Methods such as pearson's chi square test and regression model (R^2) which is a statistical measures used to find whether there is correlation between a dependent and independent variable. v^2=u^2+2as

Please give me one reason to believe that the C-13/C-12 ratio would just fall naturally which all the while just happening to coincide with the start of the industrial revolution. It is true that correlation does not equal causation just like if a detective is suspects a random Joe of being a midnight serial killer because he's never home at midnight doesn't mean he is a serial killer it could be a coincidence but it's worth investigating. However, if it is further revealed that he has had a bad history with women and all of the victims were women then that really increases suspicion. It looks more and more likely that he did it but it could still all be a coincidence and now lets say this random joe used a chain saw on all of his victims and we find that he usually works with chain saws and thus has easy access to them. This piece of evidence by itself does not mean he is the killer but combined with all the other pieces of evidence it looks like he is, more than likely, the killer. 


It's the same with climate change. C14/C12 ratio has been decreasing since the start of the industrial revolution. Now volcanoes could have caused this but that is ruled out due to the fact that C13/C-12 ratio is also decreasing. This could only be due to fossil fuel combustion as plants prefer C12. This fall has been found to have started during the advent of the industrial revolution. 

Why CO2? Why doo we think CO2 is the culprit? Well it's a greenhouse gas. This is due to the fact that CO2 is polar. Thus is able to absorb IR strongly. It could be solar radiation causing the warming but that does not explain the change in the C13/C12 ratio. Nor does it explain why it's occurring so quickly. The relationship between  CO2 increase and temp change is a natural log one. Basically if CO2 is doubled temp increases by 1 degree C. For more info just click on this link 

http://www.globalwarmingequation.info/#:~:text=global%20warming%20equation%20%2D%20derivation%20and%20application%20to%20climate%20change&text=How%20much%20warming%20does%20carbon,F%20%3D%205.35%20ln%20C.

And work through it. 

Water is also a greenhouse gas. Why isn't it being considered as the cause. Well because it's a cycle. The amount of water in the atmosphere a kind of constant due to this plus the fact that we don't actively pump water into the atmosphere like we do CO2. Although more water may end up in the atmosphere due to the rising temperatures exacerbating the problem. We are pumping CO2 in the atmosphere faster than plants can sequester it hence a net gain of CO2. 
Remember what the scientist said in this video? Solar irradiance exiting the earth is decreasing. All the while CO2 in the atmosphere (a known greenhouse gas) is also increasing. Correlation does not equal causation this is true, however combined with other evidences... it is looking more than likely that CO2 is the culprit.

author: Albert Rogers

text:
Ordinary folk tend to believe whatever their neighbours believe, or nowadays whatever their favourite TV channels broadcast. If wind turbines are not in your backyard, you can believe they're a good idea if you don't know the difference between supplying as much electric energy as Google uses in a year, and actually supplying that power when Google needs it.
I imagine that Google, unlike me, needs a pretty steady supply of power night and day, plus air conditioning mostly in the daytime.
But wind does not supply a steady power. The power is proportional to the cube of the wind speed. So at less than the speed at which it exceeds what the turbine dare use without letting some wind slip past (it's called feathering the blades), when the wind speed drops 10%, the power drops 27% . You cannot stack electric energy like coal or cordwood.
So in the first place, it is useless for the total elimination of fossil carbon, in fact it encourages gas turbine use.

But I have a strong suspicion that the widely held association of the existence of global warming, with the supposed cure of solar-origin "renewable energy",  is a gift to those who deny global warming.
Among people who are more intimately offended by wind turbines or to whom dependence upon bright sunny skies is absurd, I suspect that there are doubters who conclude that the cure isn't working, wind turbines and solar PV are an expensive swindle, and therefore  global warming is a scam.

As one who detests wind turbines defiling pristine moorland and mountains, not to mention killing bats and rare big birds, I visit anti-wind-turbine groups, and post denials of the conclusion that AGW is a false doctrine, even although solar renewable energy is a delusion.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
The correct term is Global Warming, and it is Anthropo-generated. 
Climate and weather modelling are fiendishly difficult, but  any person aware of the simplest "Laws of Thermodynamics" must know the fact that the surfaces of this planet must either emit as much energy back to outer space as what comes in from the sun, or retain more heat energy day after day. Slightly less well known is the fact that the outgoing radiation is mostly in the infrared range, which even ice emits in the darkness. In daytime it quite usefully reflects incident radiation.
Anybody qualified to call him- or herself a "climate scientist" should know that carbon dioxide warms the Earth's atmosphere by capturing outgoing infrared radiation, some of which contributes to the CO2 molecule's internal vibrational and perhaps rotational energy. That energy can also be shared with oxygen and nitrogen molecules as mere speed. 
The point is, that the energy would have escaped, and doesn't. If any person capable of arithmetic reads the  known facts of the rate of energy received per square kilometre that faces the sun, and the area of that, a mere thousandth of the product of those is a devil of a lot of warming, and we know for sure that burning  coal and fossil hydrocarbons creates more CO2 than the reduced quantity of photosynthesising life can process.

text:
Seawiiplay I'm actually a one-time would-be nuclear fusion student, which I fortunately abandoned for the computers I reckoned I needed to do the algebra donkeywork of solving SchrÃ¶dinger's equation. I am a retired employee of the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, and was greatly impressed by the potentially crippling importance of the need to respond promptly to sharp increases in electric power demand. That was the reason for California's power debÃ¢cle of 2000..2001, when the best peaking capacity, hydro, lacked the previous winter's snowpack and ongoing rainfall in the mountains. Its place was taken by "spinning reserve", which could be a 400 MW gas turbine running on idle, but providing near-instant dispatchable capacity of 400 MW.
Note that the force of the wind varies as the momentum of the air hitting a surface, the mass of which is proportional to the speed, and that mass multiplied by the speed is the momentum, so the force being the rate of change of momentum caused by the surface, the force is the square of the speed, and by extension the power is proportional to the cube. So when a wind power collection of capacity 300 MW is delivering 200 MW, a drop in the wind speed of 10% means a power drop  of 54 MW.
author: Albert Rogers

text:
Seawiiplay  The USA has actually solved the supposed scarcity or fissile uranium, the wildly exaggerated nuclear "waste" problem, and the meltdown problem that arises from using water as the moderator and working fluid of a reactor running at some hundreds of degrees hotter than the atmospheric pressure boiling point of that water, the problem being aggravated by the fact that the fuel is solid ceramic pellets.
There was the Molten Salt Reactor Experiment, MSRE, using thermal neutrons and a liquid fuel of uranium, thorium, and plutonium fluorides dissolved in lithium and beryllium fluorides, moderated by graphite. It was cancelled when Nixon cut funding for the AEC, and indicated that he wanted bomb making science.
The fast neutron wing began a project called the Integral Fast Reactor, and by April 1986 had a reactor that could reliably and safely breed its own fissile plutonium, given a starter charge of sufficiently enriched uranium, and continuously produce from U-238 as much Pu-239 as the fissile content it was consuming.
It could therefore be fed with, and consume, not only "spent" nuclear fuel, but even the uranium depleted of most of its fissile isotope by the "enrichment" process, amounting to about nine tenths of the original chemically purified uranium or its fluoride or oxide.
The molten salt reactor res ipse dixit will not melt down, it's molten as long as it's running, when that stops, it would go solid,  except that there's a fusible plug, that melts when power fails or is shut off, and drops the entire fuel content into a basin designed to arrest the chain reaction, and let it go solid.
By deliberate test, three weeks before Chernobyl, the IFR' s EBR-2 was deliberately tested by shutting of the coolant pumping power, and it promptly shut down and continued to cool the waste products by convection.

The essential waste from both of these technologies is short-lived, because the allegedly deadly long lived waste that to date amounts to a mere 80 thousand tons or less in the USA is less than 4% fission products, which are short lived, plutonium, which is an excellent fuel, and the original uranium, most of it with a half life of 4500 million years, and the rest so evanescent that half of it becomes protactinium 231 in a mere  700 million years.
The radioactivity of any isotope, in becquerels, is inversely proportional to the half life. This should be intuitively consistent with the fact that the hotter a blacksmith's fire burns, the sooner the charcoal is consumed. Long lived deadly radiation is an oxymoron.

text:
Derek, that's all very nice, but the Earth is still getting hotter! Don't look at temperatures in the USA, look at global average temperatures. Regardless of whether you understand Celsius or not, you must be able to see that some numbers are higher than others. 

The California drought is not coming from nothing. Denmark, on of the consistently rainiest countries on Earth, (in hours of rainfall, not volume) is in a completely unprecedented drought as well, the storms hitting USA in the last few decades are consistently more violent than previously, inland ice on Greenland and Antarctis is melting much, much to fast. Fast enough that some lower lying islands are already feeling it. The ice cap on the North Pole has melted every summer for at least the last decade. I still remember the first time scientists were baffled that it could entirely disappear at all!

tl:dr Global warming is a fact. And everything is indicating that humans are the main culprit.

author: Joe beetz

text:
â€‹Â @Joe beetzÂ  I never said we had no effect, you hallucinated that.
Just like bevers building a dam has an influence on the environment, I'm in favor of humans influencing their environment.
Because by default nature is extremely dangerous for humans.
We use fossil fuels and other technologies to transform it to serve our needs.
Industry has allowed us to live much better lives, only 3% of CO2 emissions are caused by humans.
I don't consider that an onslaught.
But I agree it has increased the CO2 concentration in our atmosphere, which is good.
More CO2 allows plants to grow better, I can provide you with many details on this if you want.


Species go extinct all the time, that's normal.
They evolve to be suited for a specific environment, so when that environment changes, some species can't adapt quickly enough.
The claim that species go extinct faster now is nonsense, only a fraction of species in the past are even known.
There's no way to know how many species existed in the past and therefore how quickly they went extinct.
With modern technology where much better able to identify species and therefore their extinction.


The power we get from fossil fuels, and other technology, allows us to clean up massive amounts of pollution that exist naturally.
Do you know that at the beginning of the previous century it was normal for a million to die due to environmental causes every year?
That's when we had a billion people on earth, now we have seven billion people on earth and that number has dropped to the tens of thousands.
So I'm hugely in favor of transforming nature, it's great for humans.

text:
â€‹Â @Strong MngomezuluÂ  You should warn Al Gore about that, he bought a mansion near the beach:
http://worldpropertyjournal.com/featured-columnists/celebrity-homes-column-al-gore-tipper-gore-oprah-winfrey-michael-douglas-christopher-lloyd-fred-couples-nicolas-cage-peter-reckell-kelly-moneymaker-2525.php
