http://www.digitaljournal.com/article/251232


Sea level rise has been steady:
https://sealevel.nasa.gov/understanding-sea-level/key-indicators/global-mean-sea-level



It's very slow and a remnant of earth leaving an ice age, when sea level rose many times faster:
https://imgsafe.org/image/7db363d06f


I live in The Netherlands, 2/3 of our country is below sea level.
Global sea level rise is almost nothing for us, a far greater problem is the country tipping over.
During the ice age the east of the country was pressed down and the west pivoted up.
Now the ice pressure is gone, where's still in the process of tipping back.


It's good that we have great water management.
Organized by farmers from the 13th century.
Sadly the government took over these organizations during the French occupation.
So we had a massive flood in 1953 with more than a thousand dead.
After which these water management organizations got a lot of independence back.
In every other country government is responsible for water management.
So it's an utter disaster.
Like in New Orleans, where they couldn't be bothered to take the smallest measures to protect the city.


Climate alarmism culture is very anti-scientific:
- Using political terms like "consensus", "the science is settled"
- Using religious terms like "denier"
- Keep making new alarmist predictions while ignoring the ones that have been proven false: https://imgsafe.org/image/7dd7585252

As to warming.
Climate alarmists hold on to the claim that it's the warmest ever since the last ice age by fraudulently manipulating the data:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6kUAtt2pXlc


We've had warm periods warmer than it is now several times since the last ice age ended:
https://imgsafe.org/image/7dd8d004aa


Even with that researchers have been concluding that climate sensitivity is lower and lower:
https://imgsafe.org/image/7e0fb0b599
This number is what effect a doubling of CO2 would have on earths temperature.
Note that increasing CO2 from 200 to 400 would have the same temperature effect as from 400 to 800.
All of this is theoretical, in practice 95% of green house gas is water vapor.
So it would not be surprising to see CO2 has almost no effect.


Looking at the history of ice ages, it would not be surprising to see we're going into a new one.
This article refutes that argument, but it's very interesting nonetheless:
https://skepticalscience.com/heading-into-new-little-ice-age.htm


Note that they quoted the most alarmist warning they could find, that I don't agree with.
Even if we're heading towards an ice age, it's going to be an extremely slow process.
So we'll have plenty of time to protect ourselves against such dangerous climate developments.

text:
Â @Wouter VosÂ  If you knew how to read a graph, you should be extremely alarmed by the rate at which climate change is occuring. In my region, Alsace, France's east, we used to have deep snow fall for as long as people remember, and long cold winters. Snow has now become quite a rare occurence. When my grandparents were young, summers used to be considered unusually hot when temperatures reached 35Â°C. Now each year we get 40Â°C for several days. Rain patterns have gone completely mad, with summer droughts lasting longer and longer over the years.... Agriculture is now heavily relying on pumping underground water to keep summer crops alive, and we are depleting the reserves faster than they fill up. Our national meteo agency predicted that in the 2030's, temperatures will reach 50Â°C in some places. It has never been seen in living memory, and would have disastrous consequences on our ecosystem, which is not at all adapted to such extremes.
You have to look with your own eyes to what's happening around you, and ask the elders about their own experiences to be able to get a sense of it.

https://www.explainxkcd.com/wiki/index.php/1732:_Earth_Temperature_Timeline

here's a little timeline that illustrates well what I mean. If you know how to read a graph, well, to me it's just chilling (eheh).

text:
â€‹Â @BRUNET YannickÂ  I don't remember what I said here and cannot view the comments, so I'm just going on your comment.
I live in the Netherlands, a country 2/3 below sea level and tipping into the sea as well.
Because the pressure from ice during the ice age lifted most of our land out of the sea, with the ice age ended it's tipping back.
So regardless of the short term climate the majority of my country is going into the ocean.
So the anecdotes and emotional tricks aren't going to work on me.

"If you knew how to read a graph, you should be extremely alarmed by the rate at which climate change is occuring."
Compared to the 30's and 40's it hasn't gotten warmer. You can always find a time scale compared to which it has gotten a lot warmer or not at all because temperature is all over the place:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EgZBoyqhFhc

There no stability in nature without humans. This view that nature is stable and safe without human meddling is completely false.
Sea levels have been rising consistently at the same rate for thousands of years.
They rose extremely fast when the last ice age ended, since the rise has been consistent, there's no evidence for an acceleration:
https://imgur.com/9Q5NcaQ

"Snow has now become quite a rare occurence. When my grandparents were young, summers used to be considered unusually hot when temperatures reached 35Â°C. Now each year we get 40Â°C for several days."
It's well known that we had a cold period in the 70's.
In general a warmer climate is much better than a colder climate, cold kills about 10x the number of people.
The fear mongering about extreme events is completely false, there's no good evidence for an increase, here's the data for hurricanes:
https://imgur.com/a/JzKYc6V

"Our national meteo agency predicted that in the 2030's, temperatures will reach 50Â°C in some places."
Yes, government agencies and other climate alarmists predict insanity all the time.
Before their predictions are proven false they always make sure to make new predictions to keep people afraid.
But have you looked at any of their previous predictions?
Here's a look at 50 years of failed predictions:
https://cei.org/blog/wrong-again-50-years-failed-eco-pocalyptic-predictions
Often the predictions aren't just wrong, they're the opposite of what actually happens.
That's religion, not science.

"which is not at all adapted to such extremes."
Most life on earth has evolved in periods with much higher temperatures and CO2 concentrations.
A change of temperature is the easiest climate change to adapt to because you can just move a bit north or south.
Worst case there's a little change in the species that are currently successful, but that happens all the time.
Here's the temperature and CO2 pretty much since we have multi-cellular life on earth combined:
https://imgur.com/AiVoGUG
Compared to that both stats are extremely low.

Finally you link to a cartoon that's extremely inaccurate and has the temperature line going horizontally so it's impossible to compare.
Yes temperatures have risen since the last ice age ended. Here's an image that's easy to compare the temperatures since the last ice age ended:
https://imgur.com/3FPKjtu
You'll notice that there's 5 warm periods in this time period, 1 of which is warmer than the current.
Btw, the hockeystick chart has been revealed as fraud and the author lost several court cases on the issue.

Finally this alarmism is even more insane with the lockdowns.
We've had great reductions in CO2 production.
Climate alarmists should be celebrating, goals achieved!
It's clear CO2 reductions aren't the real goal.

text:
Â @Chris GolledgeÂ 
I know watts are in joules/sec and joules are energy mate.
The point is that the IPCC are claiming a net man-made forcing increase ofÂ 2.29W/m2 since 1750 to 2011.
We are not converting anything to energy, this is the claimed cumulative man-made forcing on the climate system after 261 years.
Therefore it can be divided by 261 to get the average alleged man-made forcing increase per year.
Which as I correctly said, works out to 0.008W/m2.

The paper you cited was interesting as I have not seen it before.
They are claiming an accuracy of 0.06W/m2/decade; I was surprised at the accuracy they were able to achieve.
However, all they did was confirm my calculations.
Their work confirms a 0.2W/m2 increase in CO2 forcing for the decade 2000-2010.
This is obviously equal to 0.02W/m2/year.

I calculatedÂ 0.008W/m2/year; but this was an average since 1750. The earlier years would have been a much lower forcing, and later years a much higher forcing. Remember also that the 2.29W includes all anthropogenic forcings, CO2 is really only 73% of that.

This actually confirms that the effect of CO2 at 0.2W/m2/decade is dwarfed by cloud changes, confirming that CO2 is a only minor player in the climate system.
Global cloud cover fell 5% during the 13-year 1987-2000 period which caused a climate forcing of +0.9W/m2 and the observed global warming of that period.
These observations leave little doubt that cloud cover variations have the most effect on the global climate system.Â 

Thanks mate!

text: If you're confused think of a graph with time in years on the x axis and W/m^2 on the y axis. The delta-Y each year would be very small at first, then increase according to how much CO2 is released. Ironically enough his argument supports the theory of anthropogenic change. If you draw a line from the first data point to the last one on the graph, you would get a line which represents rate of change, and rise/run gives us W/m^2/year as the slope. This unit is quite meaningless though and I'm not sure why he would use it in his argument.

author: Sean P

text:
Â @sean polingÂ 
There is no fallacy.
What I am saying is that these scientists' minds are polluted with CO2; that is all they think about.Â 
(I guess that is logical from one point of view, because work on CO2 is all they will get funding for).

Yes; when cloud cover reduces, that causes global warming, which in turn raises atmospheric CO2 levels through Henry's law.
This is not complicated.
Why does the cloud cover change? This goes back to the CRF which is driven by solar activity (and on long time-scales by our place in the galaxy).

Back to CO2.
Atmospheric CO2 levels are not and cannot be determined by humans.
We are a small bit player at best in this.
Changes in atmospheric CO2 levels are determined by net emissions minus net sinks.
Nature is 96% of all emissions and 100% of all sinks. These natural emissions and sinks were never and are not now "stable" as the environmentalists like to falsely claim.
author: 1000frolly PhD

text: +1000frolly Henry's Law would imply that as the planet warms, there propensity of CO2 to stay in solution would decrease.  But, if the oceans were the source of the CO2, why is there more CO2 in the ocean than there used to be?  They reality is that Henry's Law is why, as human activity has increased the CO2 in the air, more CO2 has dissolved in the ocean, despite the fact that the oceans are warming.

text: +1000frolly Co2 is only 0.04% of the atmosphere, but yet it makes such a big difference on climate. This is exactly why humans can easily impact the climate when we pollute like crazy. If Co2 made up 20% of the atmosphere, this would be impossible since we can't pollute that much, but 0.04% is not that hard to influence. Further it's important to understand that Co2 is not only the chemical carbon with two oxygens. It is also a unit of measure for greenhouse gasses which means we create Co2 equivalents when we speak about climate change with methan gass, Co2 etc.

author: 1000frolly PhD

text:
Funny.  I did not ask if you know more than they did in the 1800s; I asked if you know more than everyone who has studied the subject over the last 150 years.  You are delusional if you think you do.

It has been modeled, measured, and observed to increase as the CO2 content of the atmosphere increases. It has been modeled with gas spectroscopy since Tyndall in the 1850s. The decrease in energy leaving the earth in the band that CO2 effects has been measured with satellites in orbit for at least a few decades, and the greenhouse effect observed to increase over a 10-year time period.
http://newscenter.lbl.gov/2015/02/25/co2-greenhouse-effect-increase/
http://www.geo.cornell.edu/geology/classes/Geo101/graphics/Nimbus_energy_out.jpg

For someone who claims to be an expert, you seem to be missing some basic understanding of what has been observed from the real world.

If you work with a gas chromatograph, shouldn't you be familiar with MODTRAN and HITRAN?  You can calculate the affect of atmosphere CO2 with them using the same principles as a gas chromatograph, and they show a strong influence of CO2 on the earth's energy balance.
author: Chris Golledge

text:
Look here is a comparison between MODTRAN and observations from satellite.  Can you see that CO2 has a substantial effect or not?

text:
The entire anti-AGW side of the "debate" (the science is settled in point of fact) is all based around pushing failed hyper laissez-faire economics when you scratch to the bottom of what they're really saying. They'll complain about the carbon tax being immoral, about making greener choices being to costly, that the budding solar industry is funded on the same kind of corruption and collusion as the oil and gas industry, that windmills are useless, that man can't possibly ruin the Earth, etc. They are telling you that smoking is just fine for you. They are doing now what the tobacco industry did in the 1960s, which is to lie to our faces about what we know to be true. And they'll employ any esoteric data point they can to distract you from the central theme: Humans are changing the environment for the worse.

We live in an age where the rich are richer than they've ever been in the last 150 years, when money in politics is rife and lobbying produces corporatist-friendly results in legislation. No evidence is needed to show this, because it makes the news every day, and people inherently know it as poll results have consistently shown growing distrust of government leaders in general. And when we live in a society where everyone is more interested in getting theirs than watching how they're consuming and living, we have no one to blame but ourselves first, and then the people that actively try to keep things that way next. The scientists are calling global society out for bad behaviors, and as usual the messengers are the first to get the knife for daring to state the facts as revealed by data. text:
Â @weunelectÂ Â Thank you for responding with courtesy. I'll admit that your view sounds more appealing and has merit, that it's all natural, there's nothing we can do about it, and everything will get better on its own, but when you claim that all scientists who believe in global warming (roughly 97% of them) are just lying to try and line their pockets that's like saying we shouldn't trust any of our doctors either 'cause they're just greedy elites who're trying to steal our money too.

The ozone layer is not only affected by radiation (something humans have caused a lot of in the past century) but also plenty of man made chemicals like CFCs. The ozone layer has been steadily and drastically deteriorating for the past 50 years, and the kind of climate change you're saying is causing this takes place over the course of thousands of years.

Your argument and the link you provided have given me much to consider (the greenhouse gasses for one) but frankly I'm just happy you accept that climate change exists, even if you believe it isn't man made. And for the record, I've never donated a single cent to any climate change fundraisers. I do my small part by mailing representatives and city council members to address this issue, or at least acknowledge that climate change exists.Â 

But I guess we'll just have to wait for the next 75 or so years to see who was right. If the world is still in order you can say you told me so. If not, well... I'll still probably say I told you so.

text:
I am writing to all Members of Congress to express my extreme displeasure in Wisconsin Senator Ron Johnsonâ€™s treatment of Dr. James Hansen at last weekâ€™s Senate Foreign Relations Hearing.Â Â  I forced myself to watch the entire exchange, not once, but painfully twice.Â  It was clear from Senator Johnsonâ€™s performance that he was not looking to learn from one of Americaâ€™s top climate scientists.

Every question the Senator asked was intended to tie Dr. Hansen to President Obama or Democratic positions.Â  Once the accusatory question was asked, Senator Johnson rudely interrupted Dr. Hansenâ€™s attempt to answer.Â  At one point he said, â€œthis is my question and answer sessionâ€; in effect saying shut-up.

I know Dr. Hansen, and heâ€™ll one day be recognized by the entire nation as an American hero.Â  He was the first modern-day scientist to explain climate change, and he suffered greatly for taking a stand.

Iâ€™ve read his book â€“ Storms of My Grandchildren: The Truth About the Coming Climate Catastrophe and Our Last Chance to Save Humanity â€“ as well as most of his peer-reviewed scientific reports, and Iâ€™ve heard him speak on numerous occasions.

Dr. Hansen is a kind, gentle, caring human being. He knows the science of climate change, and he is in agreement with more-than 90 percent of the worldâ€™s scientific community.Â  Senator Johnson, however,Â  never asked about science. Senator Johnson attacked repeatedly and closed with hisÂ  unscientific politicized statement; â€œthe science of climate change is not settled.â€

I have not slept well since watching this interchange. Â 

I will turn 76 in June, and Senator Johnson brought back memories of the McCarthy hearings of the 50â€™s.Â  Those were some of the darkest days in our history, when safeguards promised by the Constitution were trampled, just as they are being trampled today.

IÂ  spent 22 years of my life in the military, including Vietnam, served as a project coordinator on the Safeguard/Sprint ABM system at Kwajalein, and ran the White House NAPO electronic bulletin board system remotely from my living room in the 90s.Â  Today I am a student, majoring in climate and environmental science.

Because of Dr. Hansenâ€™s work, the National Academy of Sciences undertook its first major study of global warming in 1979.Â  They looked for flaws in Dr. Hansenâ€™s work and found none.Â  The panel concluded that â€œIf carbon dioxide continues to increase, climate changes will result.â€Â  They went on to state there is â€œno reason to believe that these changes will be negligible.â€

In 2000, the C.I.A. reported in its â€œGlobal Trends 2015â€ that we would be facing environment issues in the future. In 2003, the American Geophysical Union, one of the nationâ€™s largest and most respected scientific organizations, declared â€œNatural influences cannot explain the rapid increase in global near-surface temperatures . . . , and if current trends continue, by the end of the century it will likely be hotter than at any point in the last two million years.â€

Today the Pentagon says â€œclimate change is the greatest risk to national security we face.â€ Institutions like the World Bank say weâ€™re on the road to a 4-degree warmer world and catastrophe.

How is it possible that men like Senator Ron Johnson, with absolutely no training in science, are allowed to trample on the Constitutional rights of witnesses with years of scientific training and experience? Our grand children will inherit a world with food and water shortages and storms beyond anything we have ever experienced because of people like Senator Johnson.

From what I observed of the exchange between Dr. Hansen and Senator Johnson, I have to speak up and say his performance is, and was, unacceptable behavior for an elected official, and if allowed to continue, then there is definitely something wrong with Congress.Â  If America finds Senator Johnsonâ€™s behavior acceptable, then there is something wrong with America.

text:
"My written testimony documented the following evidence:
For the past 16 years, there has been no significant increase in surface temperature. There is a growing discrepancy between observations and climate model projections. Observations since 2011 have fallen below the 90% envelope of climate model projections
The IPCC does not have a convincing or confident explanation for this hiatus in warming.
There is growing evidence of decreased climate sensitivity to atmospheric carbon dioxideconcentrations
Based on expert judgment in light of this evidence, the IPCC 5th assessment report lowered its surface temperature projection relative to the model projections for the period 2016-2036...

...Attempts to modify the climate through reducing CO2 emissions may turn out to be futile. The stagnation in greenhouse warming observed over the past 15+ years demonstrates that CO2 is not a control knob that can fine tune climate variability on decadal and multi-decadal time scales. Even if CO2 mitigation strategies are successfully implemented and climate model projections are correct, an impact on the climate would not be expected for a number of decades. Further, solar variability, volcanic eruptions and natural internal climate variability will continue to be sources of unpredictable climate surprises."
-Judith Curry an American climatologist and chair of the School of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences at the Georgia Institute of Technology speaking at the Senate EPW Hearing on the Presidentâ€™s Climate Action Plan

text:
I believe you are wrong about Patrick Moore. He abandoned Greenpeace for exactly the reasons that I consider them worse than useless in the battle against global warming. 
Greenpeace is probably correct in their opposition to nuclear weapons. But they are utterly mistaken, like far too many other environmentalist organizations, in their opposition to civilian nuclear power. In a way it is regrettable that even Bill Nye doesn't get it.

It should be manifestly futile to oppose civilian nuclear on the unlikely grounds that civilian nuclear waste can contribute to terrorist or national nuclear proliferation, when we now know that China, Russia, and even South Korea have plans to build and export modern reactors of a sort that the USA pioneered and dropped for idiotic political reasons.

The total amount of not-even-spent, used nuclear fuel in the USA amounts to less than 80 thousand tons, growing at a rate of about 25 hundred tons a year. 95% of it is the original uranium 238, so weakly radioactive that the lifetime of this planet so far is about the time it takes for half a sample of it to decay. There are two reactor designs that can consume the long-lived stuff, and Russia now has a "breeder reactor" that can do so, producing 800 MW of electric power. That's as much as 320 wind turbines of 2.5 MW nameplate rating can do, in the strongest wind they can survive, or the 12 metre/sec,  =27 mph force at which they begin to do so.
To get an average annual value of 800 MW takes at least three times as many turbines, and the blades themselves are slightly longer than 50 yards. It takes an Olympic class sprinter 10 seconds to run 100 yards, by which time a turbine blade has gone past him about ten times.

This hypothesis had little support in the scientific community, but gained temporary popular attention due to a combination of a slight downward trend of temperatures from the 1940s to the early 1970s and press reports that did not accurately reflect the full scope of the scientific climate literature, i.e., a larger and faster-growing body of literature projecting future warming due to greenhouse gas emissions. text:
I would disagree with the speaker. All three atmospheres are completely different from each other.

Venus is extremely dense and mainly made of CO2 and little water. ItÂ has no magnetic field. The rotation of Venus is opposite to all the other planets and its day is longer than its year. Its rotation axis is lass inclined thantthe earths (3 ve 23 deg) so there are no seasons.

Earth's is moderately dense and made of nitrogen and oxygen (which are only trace amounts on the other two) and lots of water in oceans, lakes and rivers which acts as a moderator of the planet's weather and climate. Earth has a strong magnetic field so is partly insulated from the effects of the solar wind.

Mars has an extremely tenuous atmosphere of mainly co2 withÂ no liquid water and no magnetic field. It rotates like the earth but its year is nearly twice as long so the seasons change more slowly but the effect on the atmosphere is greater because of the lack of oceans.

author: judomagyar

text:
Â @*****Â  Let me count the ways ....Â 

1) His equations assume equilibrium but while we are adding more GHGs to the atmosphere, we never reach that equilibrium state. While the oceans (primarily), land, and atmosphere warm, it indicates equilibrium has not been reached. Not all the energy incomingÂ from the Sun is balanced by out going radiation because it is being stored primarily in the oceans.

2) He adds terms toÂ his equation that cool the surface (e.g., evaporation and upward convection) but ignores the equivalentÂ terms that heat the surface (e.g., condensation and downward convection) so his balance equation is no longer balanced. That is why the atmospheric temperature goes so much more negative in his unbalanced world.

3) The observed albedo he uses (0.3) Â is a measurement of the Earth's albedo so that will already contain any additional radiation from a warming atmosphere. By adding that in he is counting it twice.

4) He keeps saying that the Sun'sÂ radiation is the only source of incoming energy. That is not true, the others though very small (<<1%) include: internal heat from the Earth, cosmic rays, magnetic energy, star light, cosmic background radiation ....)

5) He is confusing primary forcing agents (GHGs and aerosols) with secondary ones that only amplify temperature changes (up or down). These include water vapour content in the air, albedo change, surface emissivity changes (i.e., land use changes), etc.

6) He claims that "nobody is looking at these factors", which is untrue they are widely discussed in the literature and so are prominent in the IPCC report ("for example "land use"Â is mentioned 40 times in just the technical summary for Working group 1 (Science).

7) He validates his model by saying it comes up with the same temperature sensitivity (1.4C) for a doubling of CO2 as does the fancier models. Unfortunately that is no the case, the value obtained by the models is near 3C.

8) He shows a graph of CO2 levels and temperature going back billions of years to show no correlation by claiming it is "the same planet" but it wasn't. The sun was a different intensity, the continents, mountain and ocean currents were all in different places so weather and climate patterns were very different, there was more volcanic and meteorite activity, and the atmosphere did not have the same benign (for us) composition as did does now, ie CO2 was not the only agent. For most of the time the only life form was bacteria.

9) He dodged the question on extinction during the Permian being caused by climate changes by using that same graph and saying "we don't know what went on back then" so on one hand he is relying on it for his arguments for CO2 not being linked to temperature but then says it is unreliable ... a trifle inconsistent?

And those are just some of them .....

text:
+judomagyar No, it is not enough. As the AGW theory is not about prediction. A theory explains an observed phenomenon - the fact that the Earth is warming. It does that perfectly, unlike any of the alternatives. 

The claim that the predictions of the models are incorrect is a red herring. Global temperatures depend on many independent factors:

1) the effect of CO2 at a given time when we know how much CO2 will be in the atmosphere at that time (but that depends on economic activity and how much countries are cleaning up their act - neither of which is predictable years in advance) and the same for various other GHGs and aerosols

2) how many how big, and where there have been major volcanic eruptions - that is not predictable

3) The state of the El Nino / La Nina cycle - that is not predictable

4) Levels of solar activity - that is not predictable

So what happens is each modeler puts in different scenarios with various (10s) combinations and permutations of these parameters. Then years later find the scenario that best fitted what actually happened. At best only one of them can be right. Then we see the models are generally very good. Take for example the original Hansen paper (1988). He gave just three scenarios (A, B, C) and one of them was fairly close to reality 20 years later. Guess what? It (C)Â was pretty close to the observed temperatures. https://www.skepticalscience.com/Hansen-1988-prediction.htm

author: judomagyar

text:
+judomagyar Look up the equation for the relative humidity of air. The only significant variable there is the ambient temperature. Thus if the other GHGs increase the ambient temperature the relative humidity increases and that has the effect of magnifying that temperature increase. The reverse is true too, decrease the GHGs, the temperature drops so some of th ewater vapour will saturate out (i.e., it willÂ rain). 

It works that way because the lifetime of water vapour in the atmosphere is measured in hours to days, notÂ decades to centuries like CO2 and the other GHGs. It responds very quickly to such temperature changes. Thus if you removed all water vapour from the air it would get colder for a while but the other GHGs would maintain the ambient temperature and the humidity levels would rise again in a day or two. However if you removed all the other GHGs from the atmosphere the water vapour levels would drop too and not recover. The Earth would eventually become 34 degrees colder on average than it is now. 

It is just simple physics.

author: judomagyar

text:
+judomagyar That question is so naÃ¯ve that it explains why you believe Miskolczi. 

There is not just one optical depth, it depends on the wavelength of the light you are discussing. Actually what you need to look at is the mean free path of a photon at a critical wavelength to understand this problem better. In the Earth's atmosphere for an IR photon typically emitted by the Earth it is about 70m. Which means on average an IR photon travels 70m before hitting a CO2 molecule and being re-emitted in a random direction (scattered). At the beginning of the industrial revolution that distance used to be aboutÂ 100m. So the mean free path is much shorter than it used to be so to escape the Earth's atmosphere an average IR photon has to undergo many more scatterings on its random walk (look it up) to get to escape the Earth.That makes the Earths atmosphere extremely optically thick to these wavelengths and that is a whole different type of physics. The equations become very complex depending on the type of scattering involved (Rayleigh, resonance scattering, Raman, etc) andÂ sometimes angle dependent.Â They are consequently statistically based, unlike the optically thin (e.g., the solar corona) or where the optical depth is about 1 (the solar photosphere for example) 

PS part of my thesis was about optical depths and light scattering, so I am well qualified to call "nonsense" on this topic when I see it. In fact I got my green card to work in theÂ US as "one of the world's leading experts on resonance scattering" according the INS. Only 7 people that year (1979) were granted that special exemption - one of the others was Yehudi Menuhin. So nonsense it is.

author: Yagna B

text:
The emission spectrum is different from the absorption spectrum but in many different and subtle ways. 

The absorption spectrum is at a very specific wavelength (the energy required to promote an electron from one state to another. 

The excited atom / ion can then re-emit that same photon (if that is what you ment by "opposite"). However more often than not the electron energy level decays in a number of stages so several emission lines (or a continuum) will appear in the emission spectrum that are not in the absorption spectrum.
author: drkstrong

text: Right.  Earth absorbs solar energy and emits it back into the atmosphere as longwave IR.  Co2 does not absorb incoming shortwave solar energy very well, but instead, CO2 absorbs the outgoing IR which other atmospheric gases do not (look up "atmospheric window") which results in more heat remaining in the atmosphere, hence the warming.  CO2 is not the dominant greenhouse gas, water vapor takes first place there, but as more CO2 traps in heat, the atmosphere holds more water vapor, the result is a new equilibrium at the higher temperature.
